reviewText: American Fans Rejoice.  For years we've had to settle for the dreadfully directed "Irish Tour" movie, or inferior quality bootlegs sold on Ebay. Well, your prayers have been answered.  "Live at Montreux" is a stunning collection of live concerts that captures Rory at his very best, from every stage of his career.  There are four shows (75, 77, 79, 85), each about half an hour in legth, plus the entire concert from '94, and a bonus compillation on acoustic tracks.  In all, there's about four and a half hours of material.  The sound quality is amazing (dolby digital and DTS).  The lighting, cinematography, and editing are all top notch.  The performances are superior to any of Rory's live CDs.Rory tears through "Tatoo'd Lady" and "Cradle Rock", delivering impassioned solos which are far superior to previously released live versions.  "Garbage Man" is a slow blues tour deforce.  On "Laundromat", Rory pulls out all the stops.  The '75 performance was shot on film rather than tape, and the cinematography is amazing, adding drama and tension which serves to compliment the music.By 77, Rory begins to move away from strictly blues-rock, and his music takes on a harder edge, as can be heard on the tracks, "I Take What I Want", "Shin Kicker", and "Shadow Play".  "A Million Miles Away" is breathtaking and impassioned as always.  On "Too Much Alcohol", "Out on a Western Plain", and particularly on "Pistol Slapper Blues", a textbook example of piedmont style taken to insane new heights, perfectly shows that, as a master of the blues, Rory was a virtuoso at every form.What more can be said?  This is the best music DVD in my collection.  For pure molten pleasure, it holds up against the Led Zeppelin DVD, Jimi at Woodstock, and even Stevie Live at the el Macambo. So kick back, crack open a cold one, and get ready to rock. 5 stars is not enough.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I have to confess, I'm new to Rory's music. I am such a huge fan of blues based rock and I can't believe I missed Rory. This DVD gets five stars because of Rory's take no prisoners guitar playin'. Whether he's playing acoustic, slow blues or in your face, he delivers. The songs span his career, so there's a little of eveything. What's even better is that there are five concerts here, count them, five. Where do you get that kind of quantity nowadays? Thanks for giving it to us all at once and not milking it.My only issue is that the DVD I purchased seems to have an audio problem. The sound level changes throughout the songs throughout the DVD. I haven't seen mention of this before in reviews, so I assume I received a defective copy.This DVD is a MUST HAVE for all guitar players.

reviewText: This guy was the best guitarist that no one knows about.  Best bends you will ever hear. If you are a die hard fan, you will buy this, but I think there is a better concert DVD for him out there.  But definitely get his documentary before you get this.
Title: N/A

reviewText: In 1975 a person that I reacquainted with told me about Rory Gallagher. I had a good stereo system and he wanted to bring over on of the albums he had of Rory. We put it on and the acquaintence was very pleased of the sound and I thought it somewhat good but was really into prog rock and the outlandish music scene of the time i.e Yes, ELP, King Crimson etc., so I was not enthralled with the record.I for some reason started reading up on Rory with now being older and a musician of many years myself. After going back and forth to buy the Irish tour or this, I bought the Montreaux set (will probably buy the Irish Tour now as a result). I liked and could easily listen to and watch all of this. Many turns and twists in this guys' songs for sure. He handled the guitar and controlled it. It was blues with about everything else added through this entire performance.It is funny that he shows different levels of maturity in playing anywhere within the twenty years represented here. Not that one level was higher than another but that they were just different. In the 94 concert, he seemed to use the power chord playing more with less fills in between but no less superb than the 75 concert that showed real prowess with a much more lead style emphasis.He was very good on acoustic/resonator guitars and really enjoyed "Out on the Western Plain" as everyone in the audience did also. Really good suprise with Bela Fleck on banjo playing with him.The band in general were very good in all phases of the 20 year history. The harmonica player in later years really adds to his music.I still cant believe that he puts on the 94 show and then passes away a year later. He must have been sick or had knowledge of it in the 94 concert. If so he did not hold back maybe wishing he had more time. Possibly a renewed fire that would be put out for good a short time later.Yep, after 36 years I get it..........like Jimi said after being asked what it is like being the best guitarist on the planet....."I dont know, go ask Rory Gallagher" (circa 1969).

reviewText: Even though I haven't seen this,I know it's going to be good because Rory never disappoints.I was a late comer to Rory and I bought his IRISH TOUR cd and was hooked and amazed from the very first song.I saw in a British music magazine a few months ago and saw they had a 3 or 4 dvd set of live clips of Rory and thought to myself,"That's not fair! How come the British gets this first?!" Being a big fan and never have seen him live or from other dvd's,I was curious to see him perform.Now,with this dvd I can..Judging from all the reviews,I can't wait! I think that Rory isn't mentioned like he should be when it comes to great guitar players.At least not around here anyway and probably other places,too.I think that some good guitar players are sometimes overrated,but not Rory..Buy this and see the man in action...

reviewText: I have been searching Amazon for a long time now to see if there were any live DVD's of Rory and this is better than I hoped!  Excellent quality audio & video.  When I started out playing guitar in the early 70's, I was in awe of what he did with just his guitar and a 45 or 60 watt Fender amp, while a majority of everybody else was hiding behind walls of Marshalls.With a minimum of equipment and a maximum amount of talent and humility, Rory gave us all a ton of joyous music to enjoy!

reviewText: Rory Gallagher was a lengenday electric guitarist & singer from Ireland. He could play excellent blues guitar, slide guitar, and just the guitar in general. He was born in 1948, and died in 1995, following complications from a liver transplant. This dvd is a very through, collection of Rory and his bands, performing at their very best, from 1975 through 1994. Rory's bands contained an electric bass player, a drummer, & sometimes a keyboardist.  You get 2 disc, as follows: (All performances are from the Montreaux Jazz Festival). Some of these songs were written by legendary bluesmen, such as Muddy Waters, Son House & Others. This is an excellent Blues Rock Concert & Performances!!!!Disc 1: (On this disc, Rory does the famous "duck walk", that Chuck Berry made famous. Rory is entergetic, and moves around the stage a lot.)1975:Tattoo'd LadyGarbage ManCradle RockTorn DownLaundromat1977:I Take What I WantCalling CardSecret AgentBought & SoldA Million Miles AwayDo You Read MePistol Slapper Blues1979:Shin KickerLast of the IndependentsMississippi SheiksToo Much AlcoholShadowplay1985:Bad PennyMoonchildBanker's BluesPhilbyBig GunsDisc 2:The entire 1994 concert:(In this concert, Rory performs in a milder manner than he did in the performances on disc 1, buy he does perform very, well on this disc, he just doesn't move around as much.)Continental OpMoonchildI wonder WhoThe LoopTattoo'd LadyI could have had ReligionGhost BluesOut on the Western PlainMedley:Amazing Grace (guitar solo)Walking Blues (written by Bluesman Son House)Blue Moon of Kentucky (written by Bill Monroe, the father of Bluegrass)Off the HandleMessing with the KidI'm ReadyBonus Tracks: (Some of these bonus tracks are by Rory, alone solo, without a band.)1975:Pistol Slapper BluesToo Much Alcohol1977:Western PlainMedley:Barley and GrapePistol Slapper BluesGoing to my Hometown1985:Walking Blues (a Son House song)This is a great comprehensive 2 disc dvd collection of the late/great Rory Gallagher. This dvd contains some blues rock at its best, plus, you get to see Rory playing his heart out on the electric guitar. He certainly can play the blues, including "slide" guitar technique. If you like blues rock &/or guitar rock, you'll love this one. Thanks!!!
summary: Rory Gallagher - "One of the best blues guitarist ever"!! This is "The" Definitive Collection of Rory at his best! (2 Disc DVD)!

reviewText: In Europe, Rory Gallgher was a major star. In America, he was at best a cult figure. Thus the Europeans have been blessed with numerous Gallagher DVD releases, while in America we have been limited to the (excellent) Irish Tour '74 DVD. A great show, but hardly representative of what Rory was capable of in concert. Now we get the real deal! Two discs of unbelievable energy, charisma, charm and raw talent. Finally, the evidence we Gallagher fans needed to show the rest of North America what we've been saying for 30+ years was true. Rory is probably the most overlooked guitar player of the last few decades and a man who's talent was so diverse that it defies easy definition.This set is comprised of five concert appearances at the legendary Montreaux Festival, where Rory was always treated like rock royalty. He in turn gave impassioned performances, the likes of which are all too rare in the world of rock. His amazing electric work is only topped by the phenomenal way he plays the acoustic guitar. His talent is even more amazing when one realizes that he was also one of those ultra rare "nice guys". A true gentleman, who's humility and genuine appreciation for his audience radiates from every pore. I cannot recommend this collection highly enough. If you love music, if you love the guitar or you just want to check out a legend at the top of his game, this is the place to start.

reviewText: Intense would be another word. This DVD set has rounded up the best of Rory Gallagher over the years at Montreux.The picture and sound are incredible. In this day of musical style taking precedence over substance, it's great to see someone who was a true musician. Song after song you can just see how this guy lived for the music. And the guitar playing! Just sit back, turn it up, and enjoy. Wish I could give it more than 5 stars.

reviewText: For many years the 1974 Irish Tour DVD has represented quintessential live Rory Gallagher.  This collection, however, may well replace it.  Rory was the real deal and never gave in to the temptation of the commercial route like many of his contemporaries.  Rory was not only a monster flat picker who was able to get that cool harmonic out of the string with his right hand but he was also a great standard tuning slide player.  What distinguishes Gallagher from other players is his presence, raw talent, and genuine passion.  What he lacks in vocal ability he more then makes up for with stunning command of those six strings.  Just a beat up 1961 Stratocaster (most players opt for a few stand bys in case of a string break or an open key change, but not Rory) plugged directly into a 100 watt amp most of the time provide for no BS sets of great guitar based music.  Each set is a mix of originals and cover material and he pays tribute in fine order to some of my favorite Chicago blues men.In contrast to the atrociously filmed, syncopated, and edited Irish Tour DVD, each session on this one is actually filmed, sync'd, and edited properly.  This is mostly an electric affair, but he does throw in a sweet acoustic number now and again ( "Banker's Blues" from 1985 and the 1994 medley with Bela Fleck's banjo accompniment are particularly great, but sorry to say no offering of the Tony Joe White classic "As The Crow Flies" on this one).  On "Calling Card" from '77 (Rory throws a couple of pre- Eddie Van Halen finger taps in for size).  My preference is for the earlier more raw footage from '75 - `79 as it does get a little more refined and slightly more subdued as time passes.  It is too tough to name all the standouts as the whole group of shows is stellar.Band mates change and Rory progressively fills out, but this is two jam packed DVDs spanning near twenty years at Montreux.  Disc one covers 1975 - 1985 and disc two is the whole 1994 show just a year before his death and some extra cuts from previous years.  This chronological collection is a tasty tribute to a master strat man.  Rory left us way too soon and this collection just reminds us of his seemingly infinite creativity and talent.

reviewText: I will make it short and sweet. If you are a REAL Rory Gallagher fan, then sell anything necessary and buy this DVD. I promise you,you will NOT be disappointed!! This is awesome footage and the sound on my system is excellent. Especially considering the film was not taken at the time to be used in this format. It has surprising clarity of sound and sharp video imaging. This is a close as you can get without having the oppurtunity and PRIVELEDGE to have seen him perform during his much to short life. If you've never heard of Rory, but appreciate superb, skillful, masterful, brilliant guitar playing, then you MUST have this. After seeing this, you will say-- Jimmy who??, Jimi who??, Eric who?? It truly captures the VERY ESSENCE of "THE greatst guitar player that ever lived!!

reviewText: What can I say? Rory Gallagher is one of my all-time favorite guitarists. I first saw him on "The Midnight Special" and "Don Kirshner's Rock Concert" in the mid-1970's. Being quite familiar with his work all these years I was interested in this collection. (Nice price for all this music too). It's a good collection of his music. However, I was disappointed with the sound quality. But, one has to remember that it was filmed for the most part several years ago. So, basically for sound quality I gave it 3 stars. Aside from the poor sound quality though, there are some very good performances here, especially the earlier shows. They show the energy that I remember from Rory. He was an exciting performer who was well in command of his instrumant. This is quite evident from these performances. From a guitarist's point of view this is a delight to watch, because one can learn much to add to his/her own style of playing. So, purchase this collection and study, learn and simply enjoy it. You won't regret it. Just keep in mind that the sound quality may not be what you are accustomed too.I also want to add that the acoustic sections are quite enjoyable, but as was already mentioned, the sound quality is sometimes very bad. The mix was especially bad for the Bela Fleck section. But nevertheless, a guitarist can learn much from this collection, and it contains some very enjoyable moments. You'll definitely benefit in one way or another from this collection.

reviewText: Containing four-and-a-half hours of multi-camera concert footage, this new two-disc set paints a magnificent portrait of the late Rory Gallagher, his battered '61 Strat, and his electrifying blues. The music spans two decades of the Irish guitarist's career with performances drawn from five concerts (1975, 1977, 1979, 1985, and 1994) at Switzerland's prestigious Montreux Jazz Festival. With his tough brand of boogie and riffed-out rock, Gallagher was a favorite at the festival, as evidenced by the large, enthusiastic crowds who often chant his name.This 40-song collection lets us witness the evolution of Gallagher's playing, as well as how time affected his material, band personnel and instrumentation, gear, stage presentation, and -- sadly -- his health. In '75, he's an energized 27-year-old lad, pounding out Muddy Waters songs with reckless abandon and a stinging, toothy tone that pays homage to Buddy Guy and Roy Buchanan. Two years later, we hear him begin to drift toward a more rocking sound that owes as much to Thin Lizzy as Chess Records. In this set, he hauls out his metal-body National resonator to play wicked, ragtime-inspired acoustic slide. A touch of early Dire Straits finds its way into several songs in the '79 show. Gallagher's move from a Fender Bassman and tweed Twin to Ampeg and Marshall combos gives a harder edge to his gnarly riffs, and his crowd-pleasing antics reveal an innate ability to command a big stage. These three shows capture the tone and spirit that fuel his legend.In '85, Marshall half-stacks and Boss and DOD footpedals appear in Gallagher's rig, along with flashier clothes to replace his trademark sneakers, jeans, and Western shirts. His tone is more pinched and distortion more fried, though his fretwork remains spellbinding. By '94, health problems have caught up with the great guitarist, who now looks puffy and tired (he would die within a year), and at times his stage volume seems to overwhelm both the audience and the repertoire. Highlights of the 12-song '94 set include Gallagher's Tele slide licks and open-tuned flat-top picking, and a surprise appearance by banjo wizard Béla Fleck in an extended acoustic medley.The camerawork is uniformly superb in all the shows, offering lots of close-up shots of Gallagher's hybrid picking, string bending, and slide maneuvers. As a bonus, disc 2 includes six acoustic songs culled from the '75, '77, and '85 concerts. A fitting tribute to one of the world's most passionate 6-stringers, Live at Montreux will satisfy guitar nuts and Gallagher aficionados alike.
summary: a fitting tribute to a brilliant guitarist
